journal-meta.journal-title: The Journal of Strain Analysis for Engineering Design

title-group.article-title: An effective means for evaluating mixed-mode I/III stress intensity factors using single-edge notch beam specimen

contrib-group.aff: Department of Civil and Resource Engineering, Dalhousie University, Halifax, NS, Canada

author-notes.corresp: Farid Taheri, Department of Civil and Resource Engineering, Dalhousie University, 1360 Barrington Street, PO Box 15000, Halifax, NS, Canada B3H 4R2. Email: farid.taheri@dal.ca

abstract.p: The main objective of this study is to produce a set of practical equations, by which one could evaluate mixed-mode I/III stress intensity factors by conducting a simple mode I single-edge notch bend specimen test as per ASTM D5054. To establish the proposed equations, a comprehensive finite element analysis is conducted to map the stress intensity factors’ distribution through the thickness of the specimen with the aim of establishing the most effective loading condition for evaluating the mode stress intensity factors. An experimental investigation is also conducted to obtain the ultimate fracture load and establish the fracture mechanism under the mixed-mode loading state. A set of correction factors is also proposed, which accounts for the influence of orientation of the initial crack and the applied load on the stress intensity factors.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Epoxy resins and adhesives are widely used in various industrial applications in fabricating advanced fiber-reinforced polymer composite parts and their assemblage. Macrodefects and cracks could be developed in these materials during part fabrications, mainly because air bubbles remain within the resin during fabrication, due to impact of tools and other foreign objects,1 as well as because of the formation of curing induced residual thermal stresses (causing shrinkage).2 The cracks would propagate from these defects and result in catastrophic failure of the part and/or the whole structure.

Assessments of crack bodies are often based on the utilization of the stress intensity factors (SIFs) obtained on pure facture modes (i.e. modes I–III); this is despite the fact that most crack bodies are subject to mixed-mode status. Therefore, the assessment of a crack body under mixed-mode condition would lead to more realistic and effective assessment strategies. It should be noted that some studies have been performed with the aim of assessing mixed-mode I–II and I–III fracture modes and developing appropriate equations for evaluating mixed-mode fracture toughnesses.3–5 Nevertheless, the proposed assessment methods are involved with complex shape specimens and test fixtures, in turn increasing the overall cost of such assessments (especially for assessing mixed-mode I–III fracture).6

Several comprehensive research studies have been conducted to assess the fracture behavior of bulk adhesives and neat resins under pure mode I fracture. Analytical solutions have been developed7 for calculating the SIF, and standardized experimental configuration and measurement techniques have been proposed.8 As stated, most of the relevant efforts have been expended on establishing mode I fracture–related criteria, mainly because a large percentile of structural failures gets initiated by mode I crack propagation (especially in brittle materials). However, there are several real-life applications in which cracks are seldom subjected to pure mode I loading status.

Consequently, the evaluation of the fracture response under mixed modes is important. Even the investigations that have considered mixed-mode fracture have mainly focused on in-plane shear in combination with the crack-opening mode.9–11 A survey of the pertinent literature has revealed that there are only a few studies conducted in consideration of mixed-mode I/III fracture in bulk epoxy resin. Chen et al.12 assessed the fracture behavior of bulk epoxy resin under pure mode I and pure mode III loading conditions. They demonstrated that the critical value of mode III SIF is almost equal to the critical mode I SIF, and the strain energy theory’s prediction was in good agreement with their experimental results. Most of such studies have tried to modify the existing crack initiation and propagation criteria, thereby considering mode III fracture,13,14 or have developed local criteria to clarify the effect of fragmentation along the crack tip.15

It would be therefore desirable to be able to assess the SIFs under mixed-mode conditions using a simple test specimen configuration and test setup. This practical requirement, in addition to the lack of performed investigations on characterizing bulk epoxy resin’s fracture behavior under mixed-mode I/III condition, motivated the study presented in this article.

It should be noted that in response to the lack of specific standards, several specimen configurations and test setups have been proposed for measuring SIF under mixed-mode I/III. Chell and Grivan16 and Varadarajan et al.17 geared up an experimental test setup in which a portion of the applied tensile stress could be translated to in-plane and out-of-plane shear stresses using a single-edge notch beam (SENB). This was accomplished by altering the load direction versus the crack front. Davenport and Smith18 extended the single punch shear test to mixed-mode I/II by allowing the load to be applied in a diverse direction onto the SENB specimen. In addition, circumferentially notched cylindrical bar (CNCB) specimens were subjected to a combined tension and torsion loading state in order to evaluate the fracture behavior of poly(methyl methacrylate) (PMMA) in mixed-mode I/III.

A modified compact tension specimen configuration was proposed by Kumar et al.19 for evaluating mixed-mode I/III fracture toughness of an aluminum alloy. The crack orientation angle (the complement of the angle between the trajectory of the applied line-load orientation and the crack front) was used to establish the ratio of mode III to mode I fracture. Furthermore, a correction factor was proposed such that by its application to the mode I fracture toughness, one could obtain K1c and K3c. Manoharan and Lewardowski6 utilized a through-thickness single-edge inclined notch specimen to characterize the fracture behavior of a particular reinforced aluminum alloy composite under combined mode I and III fracture. The specimen configuration was inspired from that recommended by the ASTM E399.20 Liu et al.21 conducted an experimental investigation on several CNCB specimens made of a brittle (PMMA) and a ductile (aluminum 7075) material to evaluate the propensity of a crack to make transition from one mode (e.g. mode I fracture) to another mode of fracture (e.g. mode III fracture) as function of increasing torsion stress versus normal stress. Their results revealed that tensile type fracture occurred in PMMA, while both tensile and shear failure modes were observed in aluminum specimen.

In the previous investigations, the loading conditions had been varied, and in some cases, specimens with an inclined crack were utilized; however, there exists no specific standard for measuring the critical SIF under mixed-mode I–III condition. ASTM D50548 provides the standard test method for evaluating the plane strain fracture toughness in plastic materials under pure mode I loading. It would be more desirable and effective if one could use the same specimen configuration (i.e. the SENB specimen) and obtain mixed-mode I–III critical SIFs, while being able to evaluate the pure mode I fracture toughness with the same basic specimen configuration as test apparatus as well. It is therefore the main objective of this study to produce a set of practical equations, by which one could evaluate mixed-mode I/III SIFs of bulk epoxy resin by conducting a simple mode I SENB specimen test as per ASTM D5054. In order to establish the equations, the SENB specimens bearing an inclined crack front (with respect to the through-thickness axis of the specimen) have been used, loaded with a line load, also in the same orientation of the crack front. Similar configuration has been used by other investigators for evaluating I–II mixed-mode fracture toughness of polymers.22

The configuration of the specimen hosting an inclined single-edge notch in which the crack orientation angle is at angle θ with respect to the through-thickness axis (z-axis as shown in Figure 1) of the specimen. The application of loading illustrated in Figure 1 would result in both the opening and twisting modes of the crack tip. The orientation of angle θ would of course govern the contribution of each loading mode. When θ = 0° (i.e. the crack is perpendicular to the specimen axis), it is a pure mode I fracture; however, the contribution of the shear force is not negligible, particularly in the vicinity of the free surfaces. The SENB configuration as per ASTM D50548 is selected with the commonly used dimensions (Figure 1) for measuring fracture toughness under pure mode I loading.

caption.p: Schematics of (a) the proposed specimen, boundary condition, and loading condition for evaluating KIC and K3c using three-point bend test (isometric view) and (b) the tensile test specimen as per ASTM D638.

sec.p: As also stated, a comprehensive finite element (FE) study was performed with two main aims: first, to evaluate the dependency of mixed-mode SIF to crack orientation angle and second, to demonstrate the somewhat uniform through-thickness distribution of K1 and K3. The results of the investigation led to the development of two correction factors. The application of these factors to the available relationship used for calculating the mode I critical SIF, KIC, would result in the establishment of the values of K1c and K3c.

An experimental investigation was performed to establish the integrity and accuracy of the results obtained from the FE analysis, as well as establishing the integrity of the proposed equations. The investigation included the evaluation of the stress–strain response of the epoxy adhesive under uniaxial loading state as per ASTM D638.23 Then, three-point bend test was conducted as per ASTM D50548 on SENB specimens having various crack front orientation angles with the aim of establishing their ultimate fracture capacity and SIFs.

sec.title: Modeling strategy
sec.p:
Due to the lack of unified effective analytical expressions for calculating K1c and K3c, a FE framework was established to assess the SIF distribution within the cracked body. Among the several available methods for calculating the SIF, such as the contour integral and virtual crack growth methods, the contour integral technique was utilized through the ABAQUS FE commercial code. The SENB specimen was modeled using the reduced integrated higher order brick (C3D20R) element of the ABAQUS. The seam crack and focused mesh techniques were used to configure the contour integral region (see Figure 2). A layer of wedge elements surrounded by hex elements was used to generate the so-called focused mesh configuration at the crack tip region, as shown in Figure 2. To model the crack tip singularity, the mid-side nodes nearest to the node forming the crack front were moved to the quarter distance nearer to the crack front nodes. The analysis was performed for a model in which
a / W = 0 . 5
(where a is the crack length and W is specimen’s height), while the crack front orientation angle, θ, was varied from 0° to 60° with 15° interval. Table 1 shows the material properties used in the FE analysis.

sec.title: SIF distribution
sec.p: The expression for evaluating mode I critical SIF is as follows7

in which Pmax is the fracture load, B is beam’s width, W is the beam’s height, a is the crack length, and
f ( a / W )
is a geometry correction factor. For the case of the selected specimen geometry, in which S/W = 4,
f ( a / W )
is evaluated using the following equation, and S is the length of support span (note that the S/W = 4 has been implicitly included in the coefficient that appears after the equal sign (i.e. 6), in the following equation)

The FE predictions for the SENB specimen with mode I crack and loading configuration are shown in Figure 3. As seen, FE results indicate that K1 attains its maximum value at mid-thickness plane of the specimen, and the FE-produced magnitude is equal to 95% of that produced by the analytical expression (see Figure 5). Furthermore, three-dimensional (3D) effect is observed in the distribution of K1 SIF; in fact, K1’s value suddenly decreases near the free surfaces of the specimen, by as much as 23%. This phenomenon is well known.24 The results also indicate that K2 and K3 values are zero throughout the thickness. The variation of the SIFs along the thickness of the specimen for the crack front orientation angle θ = 30° is illustrated in Figure 4. The results indicate that when the crack front orientation angle increased from 0° to 45°, not only did the value of K1 decreased, but also K2 and K3 attained significant values, especially as one nears the free surfaces. Of course, from theoretical perspective, the value of K2 should be zero at specimen’s mid-thickness; however, the FE results indicate that while K2 is zero at that location, but attains a relatively large value as one moves toward the free surfaces. In fact, the value of K2 suddenly dropped to 50% of its maximum value (on the specimen’s surfaces) within 1 mm distance away from the free surfaces and then gradually decreases to zero at the mid-plane of the specimen (through-thickness). K1 however holds almost a constant value within approximately 90% of the thickness (the variation in this region is less than 10%).

caption.p: Through-thickness variation of SIFs evaluated by FE for mode I crack normalized with respect to theoretical value of K1.
Variation of the SIFs along the thickness of the specimen for the crack front orientation angle θ = 30°.
Percent change in the through-thickness variation of SIF for various crack front orientation angles with respect to mode I SIF: (a) K1 variation and (b) K3 variation.

sec.p: The percent change in the values of K1 and K3, with respect to the theoretical value of Ks at mid-thickness, evaluated for various crack front orientation angles, is illustrated in Figure 5. As seen, there is a more gradual change in the through-thickness variation of K1, for all crack orientation angles, while K3 changes rather abruptly for all the crack orientations, and less only for the 60° orientation.

To further demonstrate that K3 is much more dominant than K2, FE results showing the through-thickness distribution of K2 and K3 for all the crack orientations are illustrated in Figure 6. As can be seen, the values of K3 are much greater than K2 (in terms of comparison of the ratios of
K
3
/
K
1
to
K
2
/
K
1
within a region of 0.5 mm away from the free surfaces), indicative of the fact that K1 and K3 would be the effective modes causing failure for most crack orientation angles. The negative value of K3 as shown in Figure 6 for
θ = 60 °
is as a result of the opposing shear stresses developed near the either surfaces of the specimens. The existence of these stresses would cause the crack not to propagate from crack’s tip at these regions. This fact will be substantiated later by experimental results in the next section. Furthermore, the results near the free surfaces should be disregarded because the classical SIFs could not be defined at free surfaces due to the severe and abrupt changes in the strain distribution (also known as the “near the free surfaces/corner singularity”).25

caption.p: Through-thickness variation of (a) K3 and (b) K2 for all crack orientation angles.

sec.p:
To better understand the influence of line-load angle on the magnitude of K2 SIF, further investigation was carried out. Figure 7 shows the effect of the applied line-load angle on the value of K2 through specimens’ thickness. The variation is illustrated by plotting the variation S, defined by

2

angle )
) /
K

θ = 0 )
. The results reveal that K2 would be reduced from 8.5% to 11.5% at the vicinity of the free surfaces and from 14% to 23% near the mid-thickness, when the load was applied parallel to the precrack front’s orientation. Furthermore, the values of through-thickness variation of K2 decreased when the line load assumed the same orientation as that of the crack front.

caption.p: Variation in the through-thickness distribution of K2 when line load is at the same angle as the crack front for various crack front angles.

sec.p:
The above-mentioned results are used in the development of a simple and effective relationship for establishing the SIFs K1 and K3 for crack fronts oriented at an arbitrary angle θ. For that, two correction factors, namely
g ( θ )
and
h ( θ )
, are proposed, as follows

where A, B, C, A′, B′, and A′ are constants that are established by performing a regression analysis to the data reported in Table 2, in which the K1 and K3 represent the assessed SIFs at the mid-thickness of the specimen. The factors
g ( θ )
and
h ( θ )
relate K1 and K3 to crack front orientation angle
( θ )
, respectively, using the following equations

sec.title: Materials and specimen preparation
sec.p:
A high-strength epoxy resin (Araldite LY564/Aradur 2954) was used to prepare the test specimens. The mechanical properties of used epoxy are shown in Table 1. LY564 resin was mixed with Aradur 2954 hardener with the weight ratio of 100:35 and was then stirred by a mechanical stirrer at 700 r/min for 5 min. To remove the existing bubbles, the resin was left in a container in a vacuum chamber for 60 min at 91.5 kPa vacuum. Molds were made to accommodate two test specimen configurations: the dog-bone tensile specimen (as per ASTM D63823) and the SENB specimen configuration (as per ASTM D50548). These molds were then filled by the resin and cured in an oven at
60 ° C
for 2 h, followed by post-curing it at
120 ° C
for 8 h. A special jig was designed to make the inclined prenotch in each specimen using a 0.28-mm-thick jeweler saw. After the creation of the notch by the saw, the notch was sharpened using a fine razor blade.

sec.title: Test setup
sec.p: An Instron servo hydraulic test machine (model 8500) with a 5 KN load cell was used to load the specimens. The load and supports’ displacement data were collected through a computer controlled data acquisition system and stored in a PC. The test speed was at 2 and 1 mm/min for the tensile and three-point bend tests, respectively. Three specimens were tested at each precrack orientation angle. A master loading device was designed in order to apply the load in the same orientation as that of the precrack front. Figure 8 shows the test setup and apparatus.

caption.p: Three-point bend test setup and apparatus.

sec.title: Experimental results
sec.p: The uniaxial stress–strain results obtained from testing the dog-bone specimen exhibited a nonlinear elastic–plastic response for the resin, as illustrated in Figure 9. Although the tensile test exhibits a nonlinear elastic–plastic response of the studied resin, all tested specimens failed in a brittle manner and the fracture surfaces were flat without any shear lips. Furthermore, there was no noticeable permanent reduction in specimens’ cross-sectional area to be measured. This would indicate that the assumption of quasi-brittle behavior is valid for the material; as a result, one can use the linear elastic fracture mechanics for evaluating the crack tip SIFs.26

As stated earlier, by establishing the value of Pmax from the three-point bend tests for specimens with a precrack orientation angle of θ = 0°, the values of K1C and K3C could be calculated for a specimen having its precrack oriented at any arbitrary orientation angle θ by setting the appropriate value of θ in equations (5) and (6). Figure 10 shows the load–displacement curves for specimens having various precrack orientation angles, θ. As shown, the magnitude of the load for
θ = 60 °
is much higher than that anticipated. The examination of the failure surface on the failed specimens revealed that the crack actually did not propagate from the crack tip in the vicinity of the free surfaces; thus, the failure occurred at higher load levels than anticipated. This failure pattern was consistent in all specimens with crack orientation of
θ = 60 °
; Figure 11 illustrates a typical failed specimen with a precrack orientation angle of
θ = 60 °
. The above-discussed failure mechanism can be observed though the illustrated failure surface.

caption.p: Load–displacement response of the SENB specimens having various crack orientation angles.
Typical failure morphology observed in specimens hosting a precrack orientation of θ = 60°.

sec.p:
As per ASTM D5054,8 the value of Pmax would be the maximum load value seen in curves, as shown in Figure 12. By substituting Pmax and appropriate crack angle and specimen geometric information in equations (5) and (6), one can calculate K1C and K3C for the given precrack angle. Figure 12 shows the variation of
K
1 C
/
K
IC , theoritical
versus
K
3 C
/
K
IC , theoritical
for different crack orientations. K1C and K3C are the critical SIFs at the mid-thickness of specimen. As seen, an increase in the crack angle in turn increased the contribution of mode III fracture and also increased the magnitude of K1. Since an increase in crack’s angle would lead to an increase in the fracture surface area (due to inclination of the fracture plane), consequently, the value of the actual (experimentally obtained) K1C would be larger than the theoretical one. This would be mainly due to the friction between the crack surfaces in the actual specimen, which is not accounted within the simulation. In addition, the fracture area is larger than the assumed planar due to rough appearances. It should be noted that the investigated epoxy resin is a brittle material; such materials tend to fracture under pure mode I6 (i.e. mode I fracture contribution becomes dominant, even under a mixed-mode fracture state). The effect of this phenomenon can be seen in the results, since even at higher fracture angles, the contribution of K1C is significant and almost to K3C.

caption.p: Variation of the experimentally obtained critical mixed-mode I/III SIF.

sec.p: It should be noted that since the fracture was not initiated from the crack tip in θ = 60° specimens, the results for this group of specimens were not reported in the graph of Figure 12. Figure 13 shows the front view of crack kink angle and the fracture surface of the specimens. When θ = 0°, crack evolved continually along the initial crack front. The shiny and mirror-like crack surface (Figure 13(b)) indicates the brittle nature of the pure mode I fracture. Furthermore, the thumbnail-shaped crack front illustrates the relatively large thickness of the specimens. For θ > 0°, not only did the crack propagate within an angle with respect to the initial crack front, but also the crack front twisted along the direction of propagation. Lazarus et al.13 observed the same behavior in PMMA and concluded that the crack front would twist such that it would finally approach to the mode I plane of the specimens. The increase in crack angle θ resulted in crack’s transition from an approximately single-faceted propagation of the crack to a multifaceted propagation morphology crack evolution (Figure 13(d), (f), and (h)). The formation of such multifacets has also been observed by Sommer27 in brittle material when the material underwent more torsional stress (i.e. mode III loading) as opposed to those having been subjected to predominantly in-plane stress (mode I loading). One can therefore conclude that formation of these multifaceted appearances (also referred to as “factory roof” pattern) is an indicative of domination of mode III loading in studied specimens.

caption.p:
Crack surface and crack kink angle: (a and b) pure mode one, (c and d)
θ = 15 °
, (e and f)
θ = 30 °
, and (g and h)
θ = 45 °
.

sec.p: To assess the crack initiation and propagation, one may utilize the mixed-mode fracture mechanics criteria. There exist two sets of criteria: (1) local-based and (2) global-based criteria. Local criteria, such as the maximum tangential stress (MTS) criterion, require the value of Ki (i = 1, 2, 3) at each point through the thickness of specimens, obtained from a 3D analysis; the global criteria, however, require the average value of Ki.28

Schollmann et al.14 developed the MTS criterion based on a 3D analysis by considering K3 (3DMTS). According to this criterion, the crack would grow radially from the crack front along the direction perpendicular to the plane where the principal stress attains its maximum value. One can link the crack kink angle, γ, as shown in Figure 13 to SIFs using the following expression

Lazarus et al.28 proposed two global criteria starting from the assumption that the twisting of the crack front occurs due to the existence of mode III fracture. Their criteria were developed by maximizing the mean value of the total energy release rate (MVG) and minimizing the mean value of mode I SIF (MVK) along the crack front with respect to the kink angle, γ. According to the above-mentioned criteria (i.e. MVK and MVG), the angle γ can be linked to the ratio of
K
3
/
K
1
using the following equations
where a is the crack length, d is the half thickness of specimen, υ is the poison ratio, and h is a characteristic length related to the twisting angle of the crack.13
The kink angle, γf (for our specimens), was measured at z = 5 and converted to its value on crack coordinate system (γ) using the following equation

By substituting the average value of K3 and
k
K
1
in equations (9)–(11), the value of the kink angle could be predicted. Figure 14 shows the comparison of the kink angle computed by the above-mentioned method and those measured. As can be seen, there are large error margins between the kink angle values obtained through the incorporation of the 3DMTS criterion and the experimental results. On the other hand, the angles obtained based on the MVK and MVG criteria are in good agreement with the experimental results.

It should be noted that one can expect the maximum error in the prediction of kink angle at the measured locations because one cannot dismiss the role of K2 near the free surfaces of the specimens; nonetheless, the MVK and MVG methods could accurately predict the kink angle values. In addition, the global-based criteria account for the effect of the facet originated due to mode III loading by parameter, h (see equations (10) and (11)); therefore, comparing the situations where K3 is the more predominant in comparison to K2 further reveals that the most effective fracture modes in the tested specimens were modes I and III. Moreover, the through-thickness variation of K1 and K3 was more or less uniform, and that is why the specimens’ fracture response could be characterized by the global criteria.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
A modified SENB specimen configuration was utilized to evaluate the fracture behavior of an epoxy resin under mixed-mode I/III. The fundamental specimen configuration is identical to the SENB specimen as per ASTM D5054,8 but in the proposed specimen, the crack takes an orientation angle with respect to the through-thickness axis of the specimen. The use of proposed specimen provides several advantages. First, the fracture behavior of material in both mode I and mixed-mode (I/II and I/III) could be assessed with the same specimen configuration and loading apparatus. This eliminates the need for more complex apparatus that are currently utilized in conducting tests for establishing mixed-mode fracture toughness of materials. Second, as it was illustrated by our results, in the proposed specimen configuration, the contribution of K3 was more dominant in comparison to the contribution of K2 on all crack fronts, regardless of the crack orientation angle (with exception to a small region near the specimens’ surfaces). It was also observed that applying the line load in the same orientation as that of the precrack front would dramatically reduce the contribution of K2, consequently validating the condition of
K
2
≪
K
3
within a large area through-thickness of the specimen. The authors therefore suggest that the creation of a pair of side grooves on the two outer surfaces of the specimen should constrain the crack front to be extended under a relatively constant K3 ratio, thereby eliminating the effect of K2 that develops near the surfaces. This postulation will be pursued in the next phase of our study.
